title: Jollof Rice
summary: A West African rice dish cooked in a rich tomato and pepper sauce, often served with chicken or fish.
ingredients: 2 cups long-grain parboiled rice (e.g., Golden Sella)
instructions: Rinse the rice in cold water until the water runs clear, then set aside.
Heat vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat and sauté half of the chopped onions until fragrant.
Add the tomato paste and fry for 2–3 minutes to reduce its raw taste.
Stir in the blended tomatoes, red bell pepper, and Scotch bonnet peppers. Cook for 10–15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce thickens and the oil begins to separate.
Season the sauce with curry powder, thyme, bay leaves, salt, and black pepper. Stir well.
Pour in the chicken stock and bring the mixture to a gentle boil.
Add the rinsed rice to the pot, stir to coat evenly with the sauce, then reduce the heat to low.
Cover with a tight-fitting lid (you can place foil under the lid to trap steam) and cook for 20–25 minutes, checking occasionally to ensure it doesn’t burn.
Once the rice is cooked and liquid absorbed, stir gently to combine, add the remaining chopped onions, and let it steam for another 5 minutes.
Remove bay leaves and serve hot, optionally with grilled chicken or fried plantains.

title: Egusi Soup
summary: A hearty soup made with ground melon seeds, leafy vegetables, and assorted meats, served with pounded yam or fufu.
ingredients: 500g assorted meats (beef, goat meat, tripe, etc.)
2 cups chopped spinach or pumpkin leaves (ugu)
Seasoning cubes or powder, to taste
instructions: Season and boil the assorted meats with onions, seasoning cubes, and salt until tender. Set aside, keeping the stock.
Heat palm oil in a large pot over medium heat, then add the chopped onions and fry until translucent.
Add the blended onions and peppers, fry for about 5–7 minutes until the oil begins to separate.
Stir in the ground egusi and fry for another 8–10 minutes, stirring constantly to avoid burning.
Add the meat stock gradually, stirring to create a thick, rich soup base.
Add the cooked meats, stockfish, and dried fish. Stir and simmer for 10 minutes.
Mix in the ground crayfish and locust beans (iru) for added flavor.
Finally, add the chopped spinach or pumpkin leaves, stir gently, and simmer for 3–5 minutes.
Adjust salt and seasoning to taste, then serve hot with pounded yam, eba, or fufu.

title: Suya
summary: Spicy skewered beef grilled to perfection, a popular Nigerian street food.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper or paprika (optional for extra heat)
Wooden skewers (soaked in water for 30 minutes)
instructions: Cut the beef into thin strips, about 1 cm thick, for quick and even grilling.
In a bowl, mix the ground roasted peanuts, suya spice mix, cayenne pepper (if using), vegetable oil, and salt to form a thick paste.
Coat the beef strips thoroughly with the spice paste, ensuring every piece is well-covered.
Cover and marinate for at least 30 minutes, or refrigerate overnight for deeper flavor.
Thread the marinated beef strips onto the soaked wooden skewers.
Preheat a grill, barbecue, or oven broiler to medium-high heat.
Grill the skewers for about 5–7 minutes on each side, brushing lightly with oil, until the beef is cooked through and slightly charred.
Serve hot with sliced onions and tomatoes on the side. Optionally sprinkle with extra suya spice mix before serving.

title: Efo Riro
summary: A rich spinach and tomato stew cooked with assorted meats and seasonings.
ingredients: 500g spinach (fresh or frozen) or Nigerian pumpkin leaves (ugu)
instructions: Season and boil the assorted meats with chopped onions, seasoning cubes, and salt until tender. Set aside, keeping the meat stock.
In a large pot, heat palm oil over medium heat, then add chopped onions and fry until fragrant.
Add the blended tomatoes, red bell peppers, Scotch bonnet peppers, and the second onion. Fry for 10–12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the oil begins to separate from the sauce.
Stir in the locust beans (iru) and ground crayfish for extra flavor.
Add the cooked meats, stockfish, and dried fish to the pot. Pour in the reserved meat stock and simmer for 5–7 minutes.
Add the spinach or ugu leaves, stir gently, and cook for another 3–5 minutes until the leaves are wilted but still vibrant green.
Adjust salt and seasoning to taste, then serve hot with pounded yam, eba, or rice.

title: Moi Moi
summary: A steamed bean pudding made from blended beans, peppers, onions, and spices.
ingredients: 3 cups peeled beans (black-eyed peas or brown beans)
1/2 cup vegetable oil or palm oil
2–3 cups warm water or stock (for blending)
Foil, ramekins, banana leaves, or moi moi pouches (for steaming)
instructions: Soak the peeled beans in water for about 10 minutes, then rinse and drain.
In a blender, combine the beans, red bell peppers, Scotch bonnet peppers, onion, and warm water or stock. Blend until very smooth.
Pour the blended mixture into a large bowl and add vegetable oil or palm oil, ground crayfish, seasoning cubes, and salt. Stir well to combine.
Adjust the consistency of the batter by adding more water or stock if necessary; it should be thick but pourable.
Portion the mixture into greased ramekins, foil wraps, banana leaves, or moi moi pouches.
Arrange the portions in a large pot with a steaming rack or improvised base to keep them above water level.
Steam over medium heat for 45–60 minutes, checking occasionally and adding hot water as needed to maintain steam.
Test for doneness by inserting a toothpick or skewer into the center; it should come out clean.
Serve hot as a main dish or side with rice, bread, or pap.

title: Bitterleaf Soup
summary: A traditional Nigerian soup made with bitter leaves, assorted meats, stockfish, and thickened with cocoyam paste.
ingredients: 500g assorted meats (beef, goat meat, tripe, etc.)
2 cups washed bitter leaves (fresh or dried)
8 medium cocoyams (ede) or 1 cup cocoyam flour
instructions: Season and boil the assorted meats with onions, seasoning cubes, and salt until tender. Add stockfish midway through cooking and continue until both are soft.
If using fresh cocoyam, peel, wash, and boil until soft. Pound into a smooth paste. If using cocoyam flour, mix with hot water to form a paste.
Add the palm oil to the pot of meat and stock, then add the crayfish and blended peppers. Stir well.
Introduce the cocoyam paste in small lumps, cover, and allow it to dissolve slowly, thickening the soup.
Add the dried fish and washed bitter leaves. Stir gently to combine.
Simmer for 10–15 minutes on low heat, adjusting thickness with water or stock if necessary.
Taste and adjust seasoning with salt and more seasoning cubes if needed.
Serve hot with pounded yam, eba, or fufu.

title: Boli
summary: Charcoal-roasted plantains, often served with groundnut sauce or pepper sauce.
instruction: Preheat a charcoal grill or stovetop grill.
Peel the plantains and place them directly on the grill.
Roast, turning occasionally, until all sides are charred and the plantains are tender.
Serve hot with roasted groundnuts or pepper sauce.

title: Okra Soup
summary: A thick, slippery soup made from okra pods, palm oil, and assorted meats or fish.
ingredients: 500g fresh okra, finely chopped or grated
300g assorted meats (beef, goat meat, tripe, etc.)
2 cups spinach or ugu leaves, chopped
Seasoning cubes or powder, to taste
instructions: Season and boil the assorted meats with onions, seasoning cubes, and salt until tender. Set aside, keeping the stock.
Add the stockfish and fresh or smoked fish to the pot and cook for 5–7 minutes.
Pour in the palm oil, blended peppers, and crayfish, then stir well and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the chopped okra and stir continuously for 3–5 minutes to release its natural thick, slippery texture.
Mix in the chopped spinach or ugu leaves, stir, and simmer for an additional 2–3 minutes.
Taste and adjust salt and seasoning if needed, then serve hot with eba, fufu, or pounded yam.

title: Pounded Yam and Nsala Soup
summary: Smooth, stretchy pounded yam served with a light peppery white soup made with fish or chicken.
ingredients: 1 large catfish (or 1 whole chicken, cut into pieces)
2 tablespoons ground uziza seeds (optional for extra flavor)
1/2 cup thickener (pounded yam, yam flour paste, or cocoyam paste)
For pounded yam: 4 cups yam (peeled and cut into chunks) or yam flour
instructions: Clean the catfish by rubbing with salt or hot water to remove the slime. Rinse thoroughly. If using chicken, wash and set aside.
In a pot, place the fish or chicken, onions, seasoning cubes, salt, and blended pepper. Add water or stock, then cook until tender (fish cooks faster, so be careful not to overcook).
Add the ground crayfish and ground uziza seeds, stir, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the thickener (pounded yam, yam flour paste, or cocoyam paste) in small portions, stirring until the soup reaches your desired thickness.
Mix in the shredded utazi leaves for a slightly bitter, aromatic flavor.
Simmer for another 2–3 minutes, adjust seasoning, and remove from heat.
For pounded yam: Boil the yam chunks until soft, then pound in a mortar until smooth and stretchy, or prepare according to yam flour package instructions.
Serve the Nsala soup hot with freshly pounded yam.

title: Nkwobi
summary: A spicy cow foot delicacy cooked with palm oil, potash, and traditional spices.
instructions: Wash the cow foot thoroughly and place in a pot. Add chopped onions, seasoning cubes, and salt. Add enough water to cover and cook until tender.
In a small bowl, dissolve the potash in a little water. Strain to remove particles.
Pour the palm oil into a clean pot or bowl. Gradually add the potash water while stirring until the mixture becomes thick and changes to a yellowish color.
Add ground crayfish, ground pepper, and ground calabash nutmeg into the palm oil mixture and stir well.
Add the cooked cow foot (with a little stock) into the palm oil mixture and mix thoroughly until all pieces are coated.
Simmer on low heat for 5–10 minutes to allow the flavors to blend.
Serve hot in a bowl, garnished with sliced Utazi leaves.
